facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 497 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPEAL N0. 497 of 1970. Appeal by Certificate from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal arises from Judgment and order dated June 26, 1969 of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 145 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Certificate from the Judgment and order date June 26, 1969 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 145

facts.text: Case stated by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, B Bench, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate arises from the decision of the Calcutta High Court in a case stated by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal,

facts.text: High Court answered the question of law in the affirmative and in favour of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered that question in the affirmative and in favour of the assessee. Aggrieved by that decisions the Commissioner

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax appealed to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by that decisions the Commissioner has brought this appeal.

facts.text: Assessment year is 1960-61, relevant account year ending December 31, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: In this case we are companycerned with the assesss assessment for the assessment year 1960-61, the relevant account year ending

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued notice under s. 22(2) of 1922 Act on June 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: In that regard the Income-tax Officer issued a numberice under s. 22 2  of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922  to be hereinafter

facts.text: Notice served on assessee on June 13, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The same was served on the assessee on June 13, 1960. That numberice required the assessee to submit its return

facts.text: Notice required return on or before July 18, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: That numberice required the assessee to submit its return on or before July 18, 1960.

facts.text: Assessee moved for extension of time on July 18, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On July 18, 1960, the assessee moved for extension of time for submitting its return.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer extended time by two months and informed no further time would be allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The Income- tax Officer extended the time by two months and at the same time the informed the assessee that numberfurther

facts.text: Assessee failed to furnish return within extended time.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee failed to furnish its return within the extended time.

facts.text: Notice under s.28(3) of 1922 Act served on assessee on January 16, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter a numberice under s.28 3  of the 1922 Act was served on the assessee on January 16, 1961.

facts.text: Assessee filed return on January 17, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On the very next day viz. January 17, 1961, the assessee filed its return for the assessment year in question.

facts.text: Assessment completed by Income-tax Officer on October 31, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment was companypleted by the Income-tax Officer only on October 31, 1962.

facts.text: Income-tax Act, 1961 came into force on April 1, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile on April 1, 1961 the Income-tax Act, 1961 to be hereinafter referred to as the Act  came into force.

facts.text: Provisional assessment made on February 2, 1961 under s. 23B of 1922 Act.

anchor.surface_text: At this stage it may be mentioned that on February 2,1961, a provisional assessment was made by the Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Assessee deposited Rs. 92,294/55 P. immediately after provisional assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Immediately thereafter the, assessee deposited Rs. 92,294/55 P.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer determined tax due at Rs. 1,25,512/10 P.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer determined the tax due from the assessee for the assessment year at Rs. 1,25,512/10 P.

facts.text: Penalty fixed by ITO at Rs. 12,734/10 P.

anchor.surface_text: and on that basis, the penalty payable by the assessee was fixed at Rs. 12,7 3 4 IO P.

facts.text: Penalty notice under s.274(1) of 1961 Act served on assessee.

anchor.surface_text: As under the provisions of s.297 2   g  of the Act the proceedings for the imposition of the penalty had to be initiated

facts.text: Assessee objected to validity of penalty notice but overruled.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee objected to the validity of the numberice but that objection was overruled.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO's order.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner companyfirmed the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Tribunal held penalty to be levied on tax assessed minus Rs. 92,294/55 P., fixed at Rs. 2,737/44 P.

anchor.surface_text: On a further appeal, the Tribunal came to the companyclusion that the penalty under s.271  1   a   i  is to, be levied

facts.text: Calcutta High Court accepted Tribunal's conclusion as correct.

anchor.surface_text: The companyclusion of the Tribunal was accepted as companyrect by the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above, this appeal is dismissed with, companyts.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that in calculating the penalty leviable under section 271(1)(a) of the Income-tax Act, 1961 the amount paid by the assessee under the provisional assessment under section 23B of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, was to be deducted from the amount of tax determined under section 23(2) of that Act in order to determine the amount of tax on which the computation of the penalty was to be based

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that in calculating the penalty leviable under section 271  1   a  of the Income-tax Act, 1961 the amount paid by the assessee under the provisional asses

issues.text: What is the meaning of the expression 'the amount of the tax, if any, payable by him' in section 271(1)(a)(i)? Does it mean the amount of tax assessed under s. 143 or the amount of tax payable under s. 156?

anchor.surface_text: We must first determine what is the meaning of the expression the amount of the tax, if any, payable by him in 271  1   a   i , Does it mean the amount of tax assessed under s. 143 or the amount of tax payable under s. 156.

issues.text: What is the meaning to be attached to the words 'the tax' found in the latter part of section 271(1)(a)(i)?

anchor.surface_text: We next come to the question what is the meaning to be attached to the words the tax found in the latter part of that provision. It may be noted that the ex- pression used is not tax but the tax.

issues.answer: refers back to 'the amount of the tax, if any, payable by him' mentioned earlier

arguments.claim: Penalty must be computed on the basis of tax assessed under s.143 of the 1961 Act, without deducting provisional payments

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the Revenue, Mr. Manchanda contended that on a proper construction of s. 271 1 a i it would be seen that the penalty had to be determined on the basis of the tax assessed under s. 143 of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 1   a   i  refers to the tax payable under a demand numberice. We next companye to the question what is the meaning to tic attached to the words the t

arguments.court_reasoning: Expression 'the amount of the tax, if any, payable by him' refers to tax payable under demand notice s.156 after deductions; 'the tax' refers back to that

arguments.claim: If penalty based on payable tax, assessee can undermine section by paying tax just before demand notice

anchor.surface_text: Counsel urged that if that is not the true construction then the effectiveness of the section may be taken away by the assessee paying the tax due by him a day before the demand notice is served on him.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tion 2  of section 139. . . ., Dr has without reasonable cause failed to furnish it within the time allowed and in the manner required by such numberi

arguments.court_reasoning: Consequences irrelevant if language plain; legislature can amend

arguments.claim: Lahore HC in Vir Bhan and Delhi HC in Hindustan Industrial support computing penalty on assessed tax without deductions

anchor.surface_text: In support of the interpretation placed by him, Mr. Manchanda relied on the decisions of the Lahore High Court in Vir Bhan Bansi Lal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab 1 and the decision of the Delhi High-Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi v. Hindustan Industrial Corporation 1

arguments.court_reasoning: Views of Calcutta and Mysore HCs reasonable and preferable, esp for penalty provision

arguments.court_reasoning: Tax payable is amount under demand notice s.156 after prior payments deducted

anchor.surface_text: In support of their contention, they relied on the decision of the Mysore, High Court in M. M. Annaiah v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Mysore 2

court_response_anchor.surface_text: in s. 271 1   a   i  refers to the tax, if any, payable  by the assessee  mentioned in the earlier part-of the section. It is true that Lahore and De

arguments.claim: Revenue interpretation would exclude advance tax or TDS from deduction, leading to harsh results even if assessee overpaid tax but filed late

anchor.surface_text: They further urged that if interpretation placed by the Revenue on s. 271 1 a i is accepted as correct, the result would be that the advance tax paid or taxes deducted at the source cannot be taken into consideration in determining the penalty payable.

arguments.qualifiers: According to them the law cannot be presumed to be so harsh

court_response_anchor.surface_text: particularly in view of the fact that we are interpreting, number merely a taxing provision but a penalty provision as well, the interpretation placed

arguments.claim: Court must give effect to plain language regardless of inconvenient results

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the acceptance of one or the other interpretation sought to be placed on S. 271 1 a i by the parties would lead to some inconvenient result, but the duty of the court is to read the section, understand its language and give effect to the same.

arguments.claim: If two reasonable constructions of taxing provision possible, prefer that favouring assessee, especially for penalty
arguments.qualifiers: more particularly so because the provision relates to imposition of penalty

arguments.claim: 'The amount of the tax, if any, payable by him' in s.271(1)(a)(i) means tax payable under s.156 demand notice, after deducting prior payments; distinct from 'tax assessed'

anchor.surface_text: We must first determine what is the meaning of the expression the amount of the tax, if any, payable by him in 271 1 a i , Does it mean the amount of tax assessed under s. 143 or the amount of tax payable under s. 156.

arguments.claim: 'The tax' in latter part of s.271(1)(a)(i) refers back to 'the amount of the tax, if any, payable by him' via definite article 'the'

anchor.surface_text: We next come to the question what is the meaning to be attached to the words the tax found in the latter part of that provision. It may be noted that the expression used is not tax but the tax.

arguments.claim: Definition of 'tax' in s.2(43) does not override because expression is 'the tax' referring back to earlier phrase

anchor.surface_text: It is true the expression tax is defined in s. 2 43 thus tax in relation to the assessment year commencing on the 1st day of April, 1965 and any subsequent assessment year means income-tax chargeable under the provisions of this Act.

arguments.claim: Calcutta and Mysore HCs' view that penalty on payable tax is reasonable and preferable over Lahore/Delhi
arguments.qualifiers: cannot be said to be untenable view

arguments.claim: Penalty under s.271(1)(a)(i) levied on tax assessed minus provisional payment under s.23B of 1922 Act

anchor.surface_text: On a further appeal, the Tribunal came to the conclusion that the penalty under s.271 1 a i is to, be levied on the tax assessed minus the amount paid under the provisional assessment order namely Rs. 92,294/55 P.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: On a further appeal, the Tribunal came to the companyclusion that the penalty under s.271  1   a   i  is to, be levied on the tax assessed minus the

arguments.claim: Penalty computed on full tax assessed under s.143 without deduction of provisional payment

anchor.surface_text: and on that basis, the penalty payable by the assessee was fixed at Rs. 12,734 IO P.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 1   a   i  refers to the tax payable under a demand numberice. We next companye to the question what is the meaning to tic attached to the words the t

arguments.court_reasoning: ITO wrongly used assessed amount instead of payable under s.156

anchor.surface_text: The assessee objected to the validity of the notice but that objection was overruled.

holdings.text: the expression 'the amount of the tax, if any, payable by him' referred to in the first part of s. 271(1)(a)(i) refers to the tax payable under a demand notice

anchor.surface_text: Hence there can be no doubt that the expression the amount of the tax, if any, payable by him referred to in the first part of s. 271  1   a   i  refers to the tax payable under a demand notice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes 'tax assessed' under s.143 (mere quantification) from 'tax payable' under s.156 demand notice (after deducting prior payments like provisional assessment)

holdings.text: the words 'the tax' found in the latter part of s.271(1)(a)(i) refer to 'the amount of the tax, if any, payable by the assessee' mentioned in the first part

anchor.surface_text: We next come to the question what is the meaning to be attached to the words the tax found in the latter part of that provision. It may be noted that the ex- pression used is number tax but the tax. The definite article the must have reference to something said earlier. It can only refer to the tax, if any, payable by the assessee

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definite article 'the' creates referential link to antecedent phrase in same provision; s.2(43) definition of 'tax' does not override due to specific 'the tax'

holdings.text: Tribunal was right that penalty under s.271(1)(a)(i) to be computed by deducting amount paid under provisional assessment u/s 23B of 1922 Act from tax determined u/s 23(2)

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above, this appeal is dismissed with, costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies above interpretations to facts: provisional payment deducted in computing 'tax payable' for penalty base; upholds Tribunal/High Court

holdings.text: where language of taxing/penalty provision admits two reasonable constructions, adopt that favouring assessee

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the acceptance of one or the other interpretation sought to be placed on S. 271  1   a   i  by the parties would lead to some inconvenient result, but the duty of the court is to read the section, understand its language and give effect to the same. If the language is plain, the fact that the consequence of giving effect to it. may lead to some absurd result is number a factor to be taken into account in interpreting a provision. ... On the other hand, if two reasonable constructions of a taxing provision are possible that construction which favours the assessee must be adopted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled rule reinforced for penalty provisions; applied here as s.271(1)(a)(i) ambiguous; prefers Calcutta/Mysore HCs over Lahore/Delhi HCs

holdings.text: s.2(43) definition of 'tax' overridden by contextual 'the tax' referring back within s.271(1)(a)(i)

anchor.surface_text: It is true the expression tax is defined in s. 2 43  thus tax in relation to the assessment year commencing on the 1st day of April, 1965 and any subsequent assessment year means income-tax chargeable under the provisions of this Act. ... But the difficulty in this case is, as mentioned earlier the expression used is number tax but the tax. That expression can be reasonably understood as referring to the expression earlier used in the provision namely the amount of the tax, if any payable by the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific referential usage in provision trumps general definition
